The terminal also holds annual meeting and communication with the County LEPC to discuss emergency response activities

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY EPA FACILITY 
Phillips 66 is continually striving to make the Terminal the safest and most reliable workplace possible for its employees, neighbors, and community. The facility's focus is safe, reliable, and environmentally sound operations. The goal of the Terminal is to demonstrate continuous improvement in its health, environmental and safety performance. In addition, Phillips 66 will work cooperatively with our neighbors to ensure the health, environment, safety, and security of the Terminal and surrounding community. A project PHA was conducted to improved process safety using LOPA for assessing high consequence scenarios. PHA/LOPA recommendations are tracked and completed in a timely manner.

SM regulation requirements. The following accident prevention programs are in place at the Terminal: 
1.	Employee Participation, 
2.	Process Safety Information, 
3.	Process Hazard Analysis (PHA), 
4.	Standard Operating Procedures,
5.	Operator Training, 
6.	Contractors, 
7.	Pre-startup Safety Review, 
8.	Mechanical Integrity,
9.	Hazardous Work Authorization (Hot Work, etc.), 
10.	Management of Change,
11.	Incident Investigation, 
12.	Emergency Procedures/Planning, 
13.	Compliance Audits, and 
14.	Trade Secrets

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY 
The RMP rule requires facilities to compile a 5-Year Accident History for all RMP regulated substances in covered processes at the facility. As part of the ongoing PSM Program, the facility documents and tracks all incidents and near misses that occur within the facility. This incident database serves as the basis for the five-year accident history. 
RMP requires facilities to report any incident from a covered process involving a regulated substance and resulting in any of the following:
•	Onsite deaths, injuries, or significant property damage 
•	Offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, or environmental damage
This is a newly built facility therefore, there are no RMP accidents/incidents to report. 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM 
The Terminal Response Plan provides the essential planning and training for protecting employees, the public, and the environment during emergency situations. Contained within the Plan are written procedures that outline the actions to be taken for various types of emergencies that could occur in the facility. These emergencies may include airborne releases of flammable materials, spills to the water or ground, fires, explosions, and personnel medical emergencies. 
As a responsible owner operator of a stationary source, in compliance with 68.210(b), the terminal will hold a public meeting to provide information required under §68.42(b), no later than 90 days after any RMP

the Terminal are classified as Program Level 3 under the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency’s (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) regulation.

HAZARD ASSESSMENT RESULTS
The objectives of this hazard assessment are twofold: (1) satisfy the requirements of the RMP regulation and (2) provide Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA) information that will help local emergency planning officials improve community emergency response in the event of an accidental release at the site. Due to the nature of covered substances (propane, butane), OCA focused on potential releases of flammable materials. In modeling flammable materials, the stationary source is required to present distances to endpoints resulting from any of the following: 
•	Explosion: Overpressure of 1 Psig 
•	Radiant Heat/Fire: Radiant heat of 5 kW/m2 for 40 seconds. 
•	Lower Flammability Limit: a lower flammability limit as provided in NFPA documents or other generally recognized sources. 
The facility has submitted to the EPA a worst case and alternative release scenario for the regulated substance held in the covered process. The facility has modeled alternative release scenarios (ARSs) to show release scenarios that may have a more realistic chance of occurrence. Even the ARSs are rare events. The details of the process release conditions assumed for the hazard scenarios and assumptions made are provided in the Worst and Alternative Case Release Scenarios sections of the RMP Submission. 

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAMS 
Phillips 66's accidental release prevention programs and emergency planning and response programs help effectively manage the hazards posed by the facility's regulated substance to employees, contractors, the public, and the environment. The covered process is regulated by the EPA RMP regulation 40 CFR Part 68 and the OSHA Process Safety Management Standard 29CFR 1910.119. Due to that fact, the accident prevention and risk management plan is organized to be consistent with the P

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY:
The North Salt Lake Terminal is committed to providing a safe work environment for employees and to being a responsible corporate citizen. Phillips 66 believes that excellent performance in the areas of health, environment, safety, and security goes hand-in-hand with operational excellence and financial success. In fulfilling this commitment, the Terminal will comply with regulatory requirements, provide and maintain a safe working environment using acceptable and proven business practices. All Phillips 66 employees will strive to identify and eliminate hazards which could result in injury and illness, damage to the environment, property damage, and security losses. The Terminal is operated and maintained in a manner that protects the environment, as well as the health and safety of its employees, contractors, and the community in which it operates. Phillips 66 promotes health, safety, and the environment through programs of awareness, compliance, prevention, and protection. These programs include a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning. This summary provides a brief overview of the risk management activities that we have designed and implemented. 

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES 
The Terminal is an onshore, light products, bulk petroleum storage facility used in the storage and distribution of petroleum products to retail or commercial end-users. The Terminal handles and stores various grades of unleaded gasoline, transmix, diesel fuel, butane, propane, and various other petroleum-based additives. 

This Risk Management Program (RMP) for the Terminal (herein referred to as the “Facility”) covers one process: 
1. The Butane Blending System. 

This document complies with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency’s (EPA) Accidental Release Prevention Provisions (40 CFR Part 68) and includes by reference the attached Process Safety Management Program elements in 29 CFR Part 1910.119. The Processes at
